content.webTitle: Farming is a fresh field for Michael Gove's slash and burn politics

fields.headline: Farming is a fresh field for Michael Gove's slash and burn politics
fields.bodyText: If Michael Gove brings the same zeal to bear in his new post as environment secretary as he exercised on schools and prisons, some of Britain’s farmers may be in for a shock. Even before he gatecrashed last year’s Tory leadership contest, knocking his supposed friend Boris Johnson out of the race, Gove was a deeply controversial figure. Accompanied by his loyal adviser Dominic Cummings, who went on to mastermind the Vote Leave campaign in last year’s referendum, Gove slashed and burned his way through decades of conventional wisdom in education – making an enemy of the teaching unions in the process. From his bid to take climate change out of the geography curriculum, to the expansion of the use of untrained teachers, to dispatching a Bible to every school, he frequently infuriated the educational establishment – but his allies insist he was working tirelessly to drive up standards, not deliberately picking battles. At the justice department, he was working on plans for reforming prisons, including bringing in league tables, before he was booted out by Theresa May. Some of the cabinet ministers sacked in the unexpectedly brutal reshuffle when May arrived in Number 10 Downing Street last summer have spent the past year reaping their revenge – in George Osborne’s case, with evident glee. But Gove, who was dumped after losing out to May in the leadership race, has largely stuck to the role of loyal Tory backbencher – albeit with a lucrative sideline in journalism. The only memorable embarrassment he has caused his erstwhile rival for the Tory leadership was by pipping her to a meeting with the US president – conducting an interview for the Times at which it later transpired the paper’s owner, Rupert Murdoch, had been a silent witness. Friends say Gove’s last-minute decision to enter the Tory leadership race was less because he craved the job for himself and more a kamikaze bid to save Britain from his old Oxford rival Boris Johnson – whose leadership campaign he was meant to be in charge of. Johnson tweeted his reaction to the appointment: Gove’s late entry into the running, just hours before Johnson had invited journalists and political backers to a Mayfair hotel to launch his own candidacy, was regarded by many of his colleagues as an act of ruthless betrayal. Johnson was the affable public face of Brexit; but many senior Tories believe Gove brought an intellectual heft that helped make the cause politically respectable. Downing Street suggested that Gove’s appointment was a “bold move”, underlining erstwhile rivals, as she rebuilds her authority in the wake of Thursday’s general election result. But government sources suggested Gove had already patched up his differences with team May and even with the now-departed Fiona Hill, who was sacked from her post as adviser to May in the Home Office after briefing against him to the press. The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs faces some of the toughest challenges of any Whitehall department as Brexit looms. The EU Common Agricultural Policy, which many farmers rely on for a significant chunk of their income, will have to be replaced with a UK-focused system. And the Common Fisheries Policy, which Gove blamed for the loss of his father’s fish-processing business, is also likely to have to be replaced with a new arrangement. Allies said Gove’s fearsome intellect and enthusiasm for the nitty-gritty details of policy would serve him well in the new role – but it is unclear whether May’s government will survive long enough for anyone to find out.
